abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, and project sustainability is likely, The
            performances of the World Bank and the Borrower are rated
            satisfactory overall.  There are several lessons to be
            learned from this Project. They include:  (1) ADMINISTRATION
            AND COORDINATION OF THE PROJECT: The volatile Albanian
            public service and its low-level salaries generated
            continuous changes in the Project Implementation Unit (PIU)
            at the start of the Project, with subsequent interruptions
            and damaging consequences in the day-to-day administration
            and coordination of the Project. The Project worked out this
            situation through the establishment, in December 1999, of a
            PIU composed of three competent private consultants (former
            public officials) selected under public competition,
            seconded by the expatriate project coordinator, and paid
            with local market fees. This decision assured a better
            administration and a more efficient coordination to the
            Project. A lesson learned is to apply this PIU system
            initiated under the Project to future projects.  (2)
            CO-FINANCING AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT EFFICIENCY: To achieve
            the potential benefits of donors' partnership, joint
            financing should be sought. An alternative to joint
            financing could be establishing - in every parallel
            financing project - a contractual requirement for every
            donor, guaranteeing the provision and delivery of its
            contribution in accordance with the appraised Project
            Implementation Plan.  (3) GENERATION OF EMPLOYMENT UNDER THE
            PROJECT: The project provides important qualitative and
            quantitative information on how to use road investment in
            the fight against poverty, and on how to relate, in economic
            and social terms, the overall economic feasibility of the
            Project to the viability of alleviating poverty in the
            Project area. In the future apply consistently, during
            project implementation, the monitoring system used here.
            Future comparisons would help to determine which
            implementation procedure is the most efficient and
            appropriate to generate local employment. An assessment of
            the investment required to overcome the poverty status of
            the project area through employment is also possible.  (4)
            LAND EXPROPRIATION: A lesson learned under the Project is
            not to make effective the provision of funds for any
            component before all related expropriation issues have been
            resolved, so implementation of the component can proceed
            undisturbed. The recent establishment of an Expropriation
            Department within the GRD with guidelines on the
            expropriation procedures, is a Project achievement which
            will facilitate the application of this lesson. (5) ROAD
            SAFETY UNDER THE PROJECT: A lesson learned is that
            establishment and immediate operational capacity of a
            National Road Safety Council are required to achieve road
            safety efficiency, and that initial operational funds should
            be included in the Project. (6) PROJECT DATA BANK, PAVEMENT
            AND BRIDGE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS: The establishment and
            operation of a Road Data Bank, a Road Management System, and
            a Bridge Management System, and the provision of technical
            assistance could not take place because of lack of funding,
            and no further action was taken until the end of the
            Project. Under similar circumstances, contact other
            traditional donors informing and persuading them of the
            importance and urgency of pending Project needs.
